Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I sat at my desk, the calendar notification blinking: “Team Meeting – 10:00 AM.” It was our usual catch-up, nothing urgent, and I knew it would be recorded for those who couldn’t attend. Still, as a colleague, I felt the unspoken expectation to show up, to be present, to contribute. My manager always said, “It’s important for team spirit.” But my mind kept drifting to something far more significant—my friends were finalizing their plans for Hajj this year. I had saved for years, setting aside money bit by bit, and now the opportunity was here. The pilgrimage is a pillar of my faith, a once-in-a-lifetime journey I had dreamed of. Yet, the timing clashed with work. If I left, I’d miss meetings, maybe let my team down. If I stayed, I’d miss Hajj, maybe let myself down. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I felt torn, caught between loyalty to my colleagues and devotion to my faith. My heart pounded as I stared at the meeting invite, unsure which path to choose.
